sub_Title: Digital Arts: The Future of Reality: Post-Truths, Digital Twins, and Doppelgängers and Online Exhibitions
Contributors: Victoria Szabo, Gustavo Rincon
Abstract: This session will introduce the latest ACM SIGGRAPH Digital Arts Community Online Exhibition, The Future of Reality: Post-Truths, Digital Twins, and Doppelgängers. It will include an overview of key concepts and themes, and introduce some of the artists attending the conference this year. The session will also dicuss the DAC online exhibitions program activities, revisiting some of our older exhibitions, and highlighting opportunities for engagement with this program, and with the DAC yearlong community.

s_Tag: Community, History of Graphics, History of SIGGRAPH, Year-round, Arts & Design, Gaming & Interactive, Production & Animation, Research & Education, Not Livestreamed, Not Recorded, Full Conference, Full Conference Supporter, Experience, Exhibitor Full Conference, Exhibitor Experience
sub_Title: History: Telling Tales: Stories from SIGGRAPH’s Past
Contributors: Mary Whitton, Mary Whitton, Bonnie Mitchell
Abstract: Do you have an interesting or funny story about a past SIGGRAPH conference to share? Whether your story is touching like a marriage proposal in the middle of the SIGGRAPH Village, funny like racing serving trays down the stairs in a hotel lobby, or heartfelt like how SIGGRAPH was life-changing for you, this is a session where you can share your memories. This event is a continuation of our effort to collect memories of the past and keep them alive. In 2023, IEEE Computers Graphics and Applications published The Big 50: Celebrating 50 SIGGRAPH Conferences and included over 200 memories and stories from community members. This session will be structured as a series of lightning talks where attendees have up to 3 minutes to share an interesting SIGGRAPH or CG history story with the audience.

s_Tag: Art, Community, Digital Arts, Pioneers, Robotics, SIGGRAPH Asia, Year-round, Arts & Design, Gaming & Interactive, Research & Education, Not Livestreamed, Not Recorded, Full Conference, Full Conference Supporter, Experience, Exhibitor Full Conference, Exhibitor Experience
sub_Title: Digital Arts: A Year of Amazing SPARKS in Review (Pioneering Interactive Art, Robotics, Graphic Design, Architecture, Queer Digital Art, & SIGGRAPH Asia)
Contributors: Bonnie Mitchell, Rebecca Xu, Victoria Szabo, Gustavo Rincon, Santiago Echeverry
Abstract: The ACM SIGGRAPH Digital Arts Community SPARKS (Short Presentations of Art and Research for the Kindred Spirit) are monthly zoom sessions with lightning talks and discussion. Each time they focus on a different topic and have presenters selected from an open call as well as invited speakers. During the 2023/2024 school year, we held nine SPARKS sessions. The speakers will provide an overview of the various SPARKS sessions and give short talks related to the various topics. The SPARKS sessions were: Sept: SIGGRAPH 2023 Art Gallery Artist Talks; Oct. Creative Graphic Design using New Technology for the Future; Dec. Robotic Art: Social and Aesthetic Dimensions, Session I: Social Interaction and Session II: Performativity and Otherness; Jan. Recap of Art Papers at SIGGRAPH Asia 2023 in Sydney; Feb. Pioneering Interactive Art and Artists from the 1960s to 2000; Mar. Queer Digital Art Now; Apr. Anticipating the Architecture(s) of The Future & Jun. SIGGRAPH 2024 Sneak Preview)

s_Tag: Community, Manufacturing, Membership, Practitioners, Rendering, Scientific Visualization, VR/AR/XR/MR, Gaming & Interactive, New Technologies, Production & Animation, Not Livestreamed, Not Recorded, Full Conference, Full Conference Supporter, Experience, Exhibitor Full Conference, Exhibitor Experience
sub_Title: ACM SIGGRAPH Practitioner Sessions: Skills You Need to Step Up!
Contributors: Juan Miguel de Joya, Peter Segal, Juan Miguel de Joya, Peter Segal
Abstract: The SIGGRAPH Practitioners Sessions are an in-person sessions for practitioners at the conference to have discussions, with like-minded peers, on professional development in our industries, including but not limited to different approaches to creating and scoping engineering projects, developing tech stacks, and identifying opportunities for taking research to practice and the productisation journey thereof. In this session, we will look into topics such as: - The state of computer graphics and interactive techniques applications at large; - Best practices for productising tools and services; - Creating a prototyping cycle for minimum viable products; - Prioritising customer needs, and when to cut features; - Managing client delivery and deadlines; - How to use software to aid your management and development process; - How to fail gracefully and spring back. The SIGGRAPH Practitioner Sessions are organised by the ACM SIGGRAPH Practitioner Career Development Committee (PCDC), whose directive is to plan, develop, and facilitate activities that support the career development of computer graphics and interactive techniques practitioners across different industries worldwide.

sub_Title: Monuments to the Pluriverse: anticolonial, artisanal, utilitarian new media art production
Contributors: Liliana Conlisk Gallegos, Paloma Villegas, Isidro Zepeda, April Baca, Gustavo Rincon
Abstract: This discussion features artists Paloma Villegas, Isidro Zepeda, and Gustavo Rincón, along with UCR ARTS curator April N Baca and curator Liliana Conlisk Gallegos. Artists will delve into their work as collaborators, instructors, and community leaders on the Monuments to the Pluriverse exhibition, part of the groundbreaking UCR ARTS Digital Capture: Southern California and the Origins of the Pixel-Based Image World exhibition, which is a key component of the Getty Pacific Standard Time: Art x Science x Technology initiative. Each artist's work contributes to the rich tapestry of the pluriverse by exploring issues that affect minoritized communities while challenging traditional narratives and celebrating diverse perspectives. They will discuss the integration of artisanal rasquache techniques in VR and how this technology has served as a method to produce and share lesser-known quotidian heroic acts in coloniality. Baca (Co-Curator, Digital Capture) and Conlisk Gallegos (Curator, Monuments) will provide insights into the curatorial process, emphasizing the dialogue between concurrent programming and their role in bridging art, science, and technology from a pluriversal lens. Additionally, they will outline upcoming events, publications, and community workshops designed to deepen public engagement and foster a broader understanding of transdisciplinary themes. Rincón (Exhibition coordinator, Monuments) will share on the process of VR production pedagogical curriculum in development. This discussion will be a thought-provoking exploration of contemporary digital art practices, underscoring the importance of community, inclusivity, and diversity in the digital age. All activities are part of DAC Arts Community Engagement Programming led by Conlisk Gallegos and Rincón.

s_Tag: New Technologies, Research & Education
sub_Title: LEAD Talk: Driving Global Impact through Technology
Contributors: Yannis Ioannidis, Emilia Pasquier, Andres Burbano, Sridhar Sudarsan
Abstract: As graphics and technology advance exponentially, there are greater opportunities to address global issues. This distinguished panel will discuss transformative potentials of technology such as AI, digital twin, data science, as well power that reside in our community’s work in solving some of the world’s biggest challenges. Join us as the panel shares their insights on the current technology developments, their applications in addressing issues, and some of the challenges yet to be solved. The session includes short form presentations by each speaker, panel discussion and Q&A session with the audience.

s_Tag: Gaming & Interactive, New Technologies, Production & Animation
sub_Title: LEAD Fireside Chat: Fortifying Teams with AI and Optimized Workflow
Contributors: Haiyan Zhang, Munkhtsetseg Nandigjav
Abstract: With technologies advancing everyday and processes changing rapidly, cultivating an entrepreneurial mindset is becoming more critical than ever before. Join us for an engaging fireside conversation with Haiyan Zhang, General Manager & Partner for Gaming AI at Microsoft, as we discuss ways language models inform workflows in accelerating discovery process and advancing team velocity. Gain insights on how AI models are integrated into workflows, strategies to empower and equip teams, greater efficiencies foster a culture of innovation and entrepreneurship, and more as Zhang shares from her experiences, insights and provide practical examples.

s_Tag: Diversity & Inclusion, Workforce Training
sub_Title: WOSC Mixer & Breakfast
Contributors: Kalina Borkiewicz, Dawn Fidrick, Muunuu Nandigjav, Daniel Matas, Eveline Falcão
Abstract: The WOSC Mixer is returning for the second year at the SIGGRAPH conference to foster conversations, provide networking opportunities and promote professionals and leaders in our industry. Meet and mingle with fellow attendees over a breakfast, listen to the insightful discussions of our distinguished speakers, Yasmina Benkhoui, Senior Developer Relationship Manager at NVIDIA, Chloe LeGendre, Google Senior Software Engineer and Haiyan Zhang, Xbox Gaming AI General Manager and Partner as they discuss their work and on critical thinking in the digital era.
